mindmap
  root((Laws of UX))
    Overall
        With Power Comes Responsibility 
            Implications of using psychology to create more intuitive proucts and services
        Applying Psychological Priniples to Design
            Consider how you can articulate psychological principles and that relate to the goals and priorities of the team.
    Jakob's Law 
        Users spend most of their time on other sites and they prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.
    Fitts's Law 
        The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target.
    Hick's Law 
        The time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices available
    Miller's Law 
        The average person can keep only 7, plus or minus 2, items in working memory.
    Postel's Law
        Be conservative in what you do, be liberal in what you accept from others.
    Peak-End Rule 
        People judge an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak and at its end, rather than the total sum or average of every moment of the experience.
    Aesthetic-Usability Effect 
        Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design thats more usable.
    von Restorff Effect 
        When multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered.
    Tesler's Law 
        Also known as the law of conservation and complexity, states that for any system there is an amount of compolexity that cannot be reduced.
            cf Edgar Djikstra in. programming
    Doherty Threshold 
        Productivity soars when a computer and its users interract at a pace that ensures that neither has to wait on the other.
            Notionally less than 400ms 
                Performance is important in usability
